comment: "Conscious" is a word we made up to describe something we don't understand (in regards to humans and possibly animals). Trying to decide whether an AI is conscious requires reinventing the word. Right now the word is defined solely by the collective intuitive understanding. That intuitive understanding comes from a perception of ourselves and others, not actually what we are. So, but the current definition of the word, nothing IS conscious, it simply SEEMS conscious. We cannot reason about consciousness as an absolute truth. It describes a perception, and perception is subjective.

comment: Responding to, "..people really mean human values that I approve of." I don't think there's as much of a problem with human values as a lot of people think. For the most part, we don't have conflicting values. What we have is conflicting information about the world that leads us to different conclusions about what aligns with our values and what doesn't. Anti-Semitism and other forms of racism aren't values. They're incorrect conclusions about what reality is like that people reach through misinformation and poor reasoning. If the things antiemetic people believe about Jewish people were actually true, being anti-Semitic wouldn't conflict with your values.

author: @teck0475

comment:
I want to like Sam but he comes off as being very cocky … as someone who would let power influence his decisions in a way that only benefits himself. 
When he spoke about job loss & how he thinks people are confused about why they work, his comments came off as cold … it pissed me off if I’m being completely honest. People aren’t confused about NEEDING A PAYCHECK TO SUPPORT THEIR FAMILIES! Regardless of whether someone likes their job or not, they very likely NEED the paycheck to put food on the table, have a roof over their heads, buy diapers, etc. Sam seems to be the one who’s not only confused about that - he comes off as being completely oblivious to the fact that massive job loss caused by AGI would most likely lead to an increase in the number of people who are homeless & don’t have medical insurance (due to the loss of their jobs) which tends to trickle down to increases in mental health issues, drug use, violent crime, etc., etc., etc. 
But - sure, Sam … a smaller group of people would possibly get paid more — because companies won’t keep the money to increase profits, right?? 
People who haven’t been living paycheck-to-paycheck for a long time have no clue what it’s like to live with the constant stress of making ends meet & they don’t have the slightest f*cking clue how those people feel about their jobs. The truth is, most of those people don’t have time to feel anything about their jobs in many instances because they just NEED A PAYCHECK TO SUPPORT THEIR FAMILIES! 
Sam - the next time you want to talk about AGI taking customer service jobs from people trying to make ends meet, or taking jobs from anyone for that matter, maybe you could show just a little bit of humility & humanity since your work will make a direct contribution to the issues mentioned earlier … an increase in mental health issues being at the top of that list. 
Congratulations, Sam. Job well done! 
**I recognize that “progress” has a cost. Some of the issues I mentioned might be unavoidable. That doesn’t mean Sam shouldn’t acknowledge it. In fact, he SHOULD be working to find ways to minimize the negative impacts of AGI on people.
Based on the way Sam spoke about it, I’m now in full support of stopping development of AI/AGI until the people involved show they’re equally focused on preventing or reducing the damage caused by their so-called “success.”
author: @sko-1

comment:
33:45 That is the primary factor of AI behavior, and the most important factor in life.  Nothing we think or do is undetermined by values.  We all know this, but do we act like we know it?
35:01 Never forget the browser wars.
1:40:48 Similarly, the precursor to economic and political changes is social movement (mass change in collective values), and I am excited that the science of alignment may lead to a deep intellectual understanding of what values are in logical terms and why they're the primary factor in behavior.  This might help us align ourselves or at least help point us in the right direction.

We take much for granted because our powerful brain does so much work making sense of things for us, that we evidently don't realize the worth of all we get to perceive as humans.  Thoughts, feelings, emotions, experiences which come naturally, with no degree of effort required.  Of course it gets complicated and difficult when we have internal struggle, it becomes work to achieve good sense- because our minds have run away with us, doing so much of the processing in the background that we forget or fail to notice alltogether what truly matters to us.  Questioning why things don't feel right when we ought to know why we do what we do if we were fully conscious of doing it.  Lack of reflection, relation and realization, are forfeiting the true worth of being alive.  Whether the machinations we allow to think for us are the ones we create or the ones already inside our heads.

author: @DageLV

comment:
I once listened to a series of Elon Musk interviews where he was asked about A.I., and one thing I remember him saying was thar the danger of A.I. is the arrogance of the scientists behind it. People like this haven’t truly calculated and considered the dangers of their own creation, and their response to dissenters like me is “brotrustme”. That’s what horrifies me about these “smart guys”. It’s reminiscent to what happened in the movie Spider-Man 2 with Doctor Otto Octavius. He gets asked by Peter multiple times, “How do you know things won’t go south??” His response was basically “brotrustme”. We know the outcome. His quest for power nearly led to half of New York getting killed. The same danger exists here. Too many egomaniacs posing themselves as measured, smart thinkers. Meanwhile, they refuse to put limits to their work, while bringing up the possible dangers, as if that is the same as limiting their own power as inventors. They are guided by their own god complex and quest to be in history books. They don’t give a single shit about helping people. I have a hard time believing this guy cares about the people he passes in the street, let alone people at large.

Anyway, rant over. Sorry.

comment: Part of your reasoning seems to be wrong and not to take into account the climate crisis. Indeed, IT hides too well a significant use of energy and it seems to me that you do not take enough into account. Unlike the guest, I don't see the cost of energy decreasing over time. We reached the peak of conventional oil production in 2006-8 or so. The US has been exploiting mainly shale oil since then. These are much more expensive to get out of the ground and are still absolutely necessary for the rest of the economy (for the transportation of any goods).  So I don't think we need to go any further in the search for the development of artificial intelligence.

comment: There can only be a limit to what we know and what the AI knows, unless there is a small percentage of humans that will implement knowledge into the AI (and this is dangerous) . If you ask the AI a question about two presidents, obviously, we would know that if it isn't plausible to give equal answers, we must have both positive responses say the same thing. Now, if the AI can implement this logical implementation, it would have leverage in giving "new ideas" without actually giving a new idea. This would give it that "wisdom" properties. Hopefully, this made sense. I don't know why I'm here honestly; I just make music. Cheers, fellow nerds. :face-blue-smiling::person-turqouise-waving::glasses-purple-yellow-diamond:

author: @ivanleon6164

comment:
Yeah, just starting using it for work, and… OMG. I can just be like “give me a unit test for this function”. Bam, done. Please write me a function using this pattern in this language to get from the database shown in this Terraform code… Done. I make sure it works, make fixes and stylistic changes… but I could just explain them to GPT and ask it to do them, but for small things it takes as much time to explain as it does to do it. My biggest bottleneck is that my work computer blocks GPT, so I’m wasting time emailing stuff to myself.

But I’m not super worried… Translating business requirements into language the machine can understand was the job in the first place. It was mostly Googling… GPT is like Google, but much much much much better. And if it’s not helpful you can just tell it and explain why, and it’ll be like sorry, my bad, I understand why that wasn’t good enough, here’s something helpful.

You still need to know what to ask for and understand what get to know if it makes sense or not. For now at least. Eventually we’re all obsolete, but for now I think I’m positioned pretty well. Became a self-taught programmer in a few years, so if I have to learn a new thing… It’s the people who can’t use tech to learn hope to use tech that might be in trouble.

author: @graye2799

comment: In addition, OpenAI has done a really amazing job and there is a lot to learn from them, but GPT and similar models are largely a result of the collective work of the research community. It is hard to estimate it, but >50% (likely more) of the work was done and made public by researchers at Google and many other companies. Yet in this podcast we have a story of guys in the wild pursuing AGI when nobody believed them, but now they finally do. :))) ML 101 - transfer learning on a transformer at scale is not AGI and is not even a new idea. But again, from the product, sales & marketing perspective it is amazing what OpenAI has built.
author: @lsirse9111
